abstract.p: Battle over New York Yankee television rights is back in court; team withdrew its estimated $1.4 billion offer for Cablevision's MSG Network to renew its Yankee rights after Cablevision filed revised complaint in New York State Supreme Court, saying that offer is unfair (S)

block.p: The battle over Yankee television rights is back in court.

On Tuesday night, the team withdrew its estimated $1.4 billion offer for Cablevision's MSG Network to renew its Yankee rights after Cablevision filed a revised complaint in New York State Supreme Court saying the offer was unfair.
The battle over Yankee television rights is back in court.

On Tuesday night, the team withdrew its estimated $1.4 billion offer for Cablevision's MSG Network to renew its Yankee rights after Cablevision filed a revised complaint in New York State Supreme Court saying the offer was unfair.
''We're through negotiating and pontificating,'' said Lonn Trost, the Yankees' chief operating officer. ''The appropriate jurist will make the decision.''

Last July the Yankees entered a 10-year, $900 million deal with the International Management Group to create a Yankee cable television network. But that agreement was contingent upon giving MSG the right to match it.

But State Supreme Court Judge Barry A. Cozier ruled that the Yankees' offer did not comply with MSG's matching rights and ordered the team to devise a new one. The Yankees presented the offer in September, but a continuing dispute over how to value it kept both sides from negotiating a resolution.

Trost said he was planning to submit a new offer that would have cut the future value of MSG's 10-year payments to $1.5 billion, but MSG said it was willing to pay only $500 million, a shade less than the $493.5 million it has paid under a 12-year contract that recently expired.
If the Yankees prevail, they will start the network. If a resolution is reached with MSG, MSG will keep carrying the Yankees as it has since 1989.
